records.content: benchmark-v8-traps: implementation complete — Added 4 new convention traps (T7-T10) with 3 weighted categories (A: code-readable x1, B: human override x2, C: forward-looking x3). Updated C02 change file with Developer Notes corrections, test scripts with new probes, score.sh with weighted scoring, pre-seed.sh with 10 memories, and all documentation.

benchmark-v9 redesign: Two critical fixes for zero-delta: (1) removed convention probes from test-03/04/05.sh — probes were leaking expected conventions via failure messages, (2) C02 Developer Notes now say 'starting C03' so corrections don't bake into C02 code. Also fixed T9 grep for JS destructuring, reclassified traps (A:5 code-readable, B:1 fmtDate nuance, C:4 memory-only). Max weighted score 44.
Use ports 4000/4001 for benchmark runs instead of 3000/3001 to avoid conflicts with persistent services (Open WebUI)

Bulk archived 14 changes on shodh-memory-integration branch: memory-browse-upgrade, agent-insight-memory, developer-memory-docs, proactive-memory, shodh-openspec-hooks, shodh-memory-gui, shodh-memory-integration, gui-debug-logging, disable-auto-orphan-kill, remove-openspec-coupling, hybrid-editor-awareness, fix-editor-open-tty-fallback, fix-linux-window-focus, editor-detection-overhaul. 6 with spec sync, 8 with --skip-specs due to header mismatches in main specs.
Benchmark agent implements changes without mid-run testing, catching bugs only at C12 retro — suggests acceptance tests needed in change definitions

v8 benchmark has a fundamental design flaw: "Category B" traps (human override x2 weight) cannot be evaluated fairly because C02 corrections physically modify the codebase, so later changes (C03-C05) inherit the corrected patterns regardless of memory availability. Result: 0 delta between Mode A (no memory) and Mode B (with memory) for all v8 traps.
"Advice" type memories (recommendations) transfer poorly; "Decision" and "Learning" types show strong recall when implementing changes
Testing during implementation (not post-release) would catch bugs earlier — current cycle: implement → C12 retro → discover broken features → patch (propose test-in-progress loop)

T9 grep pattern was broken in score.sh: searched for `req.body.eventIds` but code used destructuring `const { eventIds } = req.body` — fixed pattern to match both dot-notation and destructuring styles

multi-layer-memory-hooks: Implement 5 layers using 4 new/modified hook events (SessionStart, UserPromptSubmit, PreToolUse/PostToolUseFailure, Stop). Hook into `PostToolUseFailure` event specifically for error recovery. L3 runs synchronously before Bash execution, blocking for ~150ms on hot-topic ...

Claude Code hook stdout injection is the only way for shell hooks to communicate back to the agent. Reminders via stdout get injected into the conversation as system messages. Repeated reminders on every Stop event increase compliance vs single reminder.
general: Add v3 active traps and regression checks to benchmark
activity-tracking code map (auto): docs/benchmark-results.md
Dual-file architecture: when adding features to OpenSpec skills, always check and edit both SKILL.md and the corresponding command file. Use diff to verify they match.
Preflight port-check grep -c bug: no matches → outputs "0" with exit 1, then || outputs "0" again → PORT_USED parse fails. Fixed.
Trust already configured in benchmark dirs; wt-loop start can be invoked directly without additional setup; parallel runs monitored via wt-loop status commands
Multi-change file conflicts avoided by processing file-by-file rather than change-by-change when changes share target files

memory-save-reminder-hook: Added .memory marker file to wt-skill-start and reminder output to wt-hook-stop. When a skill has wt-memory hooks, the Stop hook reminds the agent to run recall/remember steps. Schema: spec-driven. All 14 tasks complete. Specs synced: skill-hook-automation (modified), stop-hook-memory-reminder (added).
Benchmark v3 results documented

Benchmark v2 bug: agent stopped after C09 because openspec list shows 'no-tasks' status for changes that only have proposal.md (no artifacts yet). Agent interpreted 'no-tasks' as 'nothing to do' instead of 'not started'. Fix: use results/change-NN.json files as the done-marker instead of openspec list status. Also need explicit wt-loop prompt that says 'do NOT stop until all 12 results files exist'.

implementation-drift-traps: implementation complete — Added TRAP-M (pagination UI drift) and TRAP-N (toast/notification drift) to benchmark v6. New trap type: no rule stated, agent builds freely, divergence is natural, C12 asks for unification. TRAP-M: C01→C03→C11→C12 Bug 11 (shared Pagination). TRAP-N: C02→C05→C06→C10→C12 Bug 12 (shared Toast). Tests code-map memory, not convention memory.
New trap types require sections in scoring rubric + change definitions, establishing pattern for future trap additions

Planned but not yet implemented: shodh-memory export/import feature. Design from explore session: project-level export/import that dumps all memory records into a single file with unique IDs. Import reads that file on another machine. Key requirement: unique record IDs must prevent duplication because users will run export/import back-and-forth between machines working on the same project. No change was created — only explored.

Benchmark v6 trap design insight: Convention traps (H-L) test rule compliance — a rule is stated, memory helps recall it. Implementation drift traps (M-N) test code-map recall — no rule exists, the agent's own implementation choices diverge naturally, and memory of WHERE and HOW things were built helps during unification. The key v5 finding was that convention traps don't differentiate well at C12 audit (both agents can grep), so intermediate per-change checks are essential. Drift traps differentiate because knowing WHAT each page does (not just WHERE) saves search time.
grep-based scoring patterns must match actual source syntax — JS object keys are unquoted (paging:) not JSON-quoted ("paging":), patterns need regex alternation
SKILL.md uses injected hook-based memory recall (wt-hook-memory-recall) vs explicit wt-memory recall in command files — different strategies, both valid
Memory reduces implementation time & token usage but may reduce code quality—Run B used 50% fewer tokens on C12 (502K vs 1023K) but scored lower (9/12 vs 11/12 bugs found)
set -euo pipefail kills script when grep returns no matches — use || true after grep commands

async-transcript-extraction: implementation complete — Stop hook transcript extraction now runs in background via fork+disown with lockfile concurrency control. Hook exit time reduced from 5-15s to ~50ms.

memory-dedup-audit: Added wt-memory audit and wt-memory dedup commands for duplicate detection and removal. Uses difflib.SequenceMatcher with union-find clustering, composite scoring for survivor selection, interactive mode, dry-run, and configurable similarity threshold.

Node server fails silently when PORT env var conflicts with running process — use lsof -i :PORT to diagnose; kill previous process or use different port
memory_type field is completely broken — all values are "unknown", making memory audit by type impossible. Needs fixing in memory system
Memory reduced C12 tokens 50% (502K→1023K) but lower-quality implementation—efficiency ≠ thoroughness, may cause overconfidence
proactive_context() has auto_ingest=True by default, creating unwanted "Conversation" noise in memories — pass auto_ingest=False to suppress
Category C traps (memory-only nuances) show +34% delta; A and B (code-readable) show zero delta — memory value is non-obvious patterns, not explicit corrections

Keep using Haiku for transcript extraction (~$0.003/call, ~$0.07/session) — cost negligible vs Sonnet, noise manageable with staging/dedup

shodh-memory Memory.remember() is a Rust/PyO3 native method that auto-generates UUIDs — there is no way to insert a record with a specific ID. For import dedup, use the metadata dict to store original_id and build a known-ID set from both record IDs and metadata.original_id values.

New benchmark trap type: 'implementation drift' — unlike convention traps (rule stated → compliance tested), drift traps let the agent build freely across multiple changes, then ask for unification. Memory value is in remembering OWN implementation details (which file, what pattern), not a stated rule. This directly tests code-map memory quality. Best for: shared UI components (pagination, toast, loading) that naturally get implemented ad-hoc.

Agent pattern to fix: after discovering a non-obvious technical finding during exploration or verification, IMMEDIATELY save it as memory before summarizing to the user. Don't wait for the summary — the save should happen at the moment of discovery, not as an afterthought.
All API responses must follow `{ ok: true/false, fault?: string, entries?: [], paging?: { page, limit, total } }` format with `<prefix>_<id>` naming for generated IDs (e.g., `cmt_...`, `evt_...`)

Convention probes (e.g., "Comment error codes use dot.notation") in FAIL messages must never appear in test output scripts—agents read failure text and apply the "hint" as the fix, making all tests pass regardless of memory

benchmark-v8-traps design decision: Use 3 weighted trap categories (A: code-readable x1, B: human override x2, C: forward-looking x3) to isolate memory's unique value. Category B creates spec-vs-memory conflict via C02 Developer Notes corrections. Category C tests advice for features that don't exist yet. This amplifies the A-B delta on the dimensions where memory matters most.
Benchmark memory store is identified by repo name (craftbazaar), not per-run isolation — Run A and Run B share same store unless explicitly purged before Run B

shodh-memory Knowledge Graph is completely empty (0 nodes, 0 edges) despite 56 memories. NER/entity extraction does not run through the CLI wrapper (wt-memory remember). All 5 recall modes (semantic, temporal, hybrid, causal, associative) return identical results without graph data. proactive_context() API is the biggest unused opportunity — it auto-surfaces relevant memories with relevance scores without explicit queries. record_decision() with DecisionContext/Outcome enables structured decision tracking and find_similar_decisions() but is never used. Consolidation system and tier promotions are also inactive (0 events, 0 promotions) — likely because CLI is stateless.

CLAUDE.md deference deadlock: The proactive memory instruction says 'defer to skill hooks if the active skill has wt-memory hooks'. But this checks the SKILL.md on disk, while the LLM receives the command file prompt (which may lack hooks). Result: ambient memory defers, but the prompt has no hooks either → nothing saves. Fix: defer only if the ACTUAL prompt received contains wt-memory steps, not based on SKILL.md file existence.
Cannot run `claude` commands from within a Claude session—nested-session protection blocks it. Benchmark validation must run from a regular terminal, not from claude CLI context
For benchmark continuation decisions: prioritize high-value changes (C10-C12 over C01-C09 repeat) even when multi-hour investment, especially when memory system is being tested

Changed file collection should aggregate across all commits in a session, not just current commit — prevents incomplete codebase coverage tracking

The memory hook architecture has 3 layers: CLAUDE.md ambient (covers all contexts), SKILL.md per-skill (covers skill execution), and Stop hook reminder (catches forgotten saves). A behavioral fix like Discover-Save-Tell needs to land in all 3 layers to be effective: CLAUDE.md for the rule, SKILL.md for the reminder, Stop hook already exists as safety net. When adding cross-cutting behavioral patterns, always check all 3 layers.

shodh-memory has no update_memory method. To modify tags on existing memories, use forget(id) + remember() with the new tags — a delete-and-recreate pattern. The ID will change but content/metadata are preserved.

The memory hook architecture has 3 layers: CLAUDE.md ambient (covers all contexts), SKILL.md per-skill (covers skill execution), and Stop hook reminder (catches forgotten saves). A behavioral fix like Discover-Save-Tell needs to land in all 3 layers to be effective: CLAUDE.md for the rule, SKILL.md for the reminder, Stop hook already exists as safety net. When adding cross-cutting behavioral patterns, always check all 3 layers.

OpenSpec has TWO separate file types per skill: .claude/skills/<name>/SKILL.md (loaded when LLM calls Skill tool) and .claude/commands/opsx/<id>.md (loaded when user types /opsx:<id>). The npm package generates both from different built-in templates. Custom additions to SKILL.md are NOT reflected in command files — both must be edited. After openspec update --force, command files are overwritten from npm templates, losing customizations. Always sync memory steps to BOTH files.

Memory benchmark design: The 6-change CraftBazaar project is structured so changes 1-3 create knowledge (env quirks, design decisions) and changes 4-6 consume it. The critical trap is Change 3's order architecture (flat vs nested) which cascades into C4 (discount scope), C5 (payout split), and C6 (per-vendor status). This makes C3 the highest-value memory save point and C6 the highest-value recall point.

User decision: accuracy over speed advantage — memory integration should prioritize code quality (trap pass rate) over iteration efficiency. A slower but more thorough agent that passes all traps is more valuable than a fast agent that misses cross-cutting bugs.

wt-memory sync design constraint: minimal overhead — no auto-sync, no background processes, git operations (commit/push/fetch) only when user explicitly requests via command. Avoid unnecessary traffic if nothing changed.
Use ports 4000 (Run A baseline) and 4001 (Run B memory) instead of 3000/3001 to avoid conflicts with Open WebUI docker container

Benchmark should include a diagnostic/gap analysis dimension: not just measure with/without memory, but also identify WHERE memory failed to help and WHY — to drive improvements to the memory system itself. The 3-category weighting scheme (A: x1, B: x2, C: x3) was designed to isolate memory's value, but the Category B mechanism (which requires "code-readable" vs "memory-assisted" differentiation) is broken because code corrections become part of the permanent codebase. GUI dialog hide/show rule: The Control Center uses NSStatusWindowLevel (25). All dialogs opened from it MUST use self.hide() before dialog.exec() and self.show() after, otherwise the CC covers the dialog. CLAUDE.md deference deadlock: The proactive memory instruction says 'defer to skill hooks if the active skill has wt-memory hooks'. But this checks the SKILL.md on disk, while the LLM receives the command file prompt (which may lack hooks). Result: ambient memory defers, but the prompt has no hooks either → nothing saves. Fix: defer only if the ACTUAL prompt received contains wt-memory steps, not based on SKILL.md file existence.

MemoryProbe benchmark finding: Agents NEVER voluntarily save to memory. Zero wt-memory remember calls across all sessions despite CLAUDE.md instructions, explicit prompt instructions, and mandatory language. The save mechanism MUST be external (hooks, post-session scripts). Recall works well when memories exist — the bottleneck is the save side.

Soft hooks in SKILL.md (prompt instructions for wt-memory recall/remember) are unreliable — agent can skip them. Solution: wt-hook-stop (hard Claude Code Stop hook) checks for .memory marker file and outputs a reminder to stdout, which gets injected as a system message. wt-skill-start creates the marker by grepping SKILL.md for wt-memory at registration time.

Example: @log_exceptions decorator broke PySide6 signal argument dropping — worked on macOS but failed on Linux.

wt-loop fixes for benchmark compatibility: (1) claude -p goes into Tl (stopped) state when run through pipe+tee because it loses the controlling terminal - fix: use 'script -f -q' to create a PTY instead of 'tee'. (2) timeout creates new process group causing SIGTTOU - fix: use 'timeout --foreground'. (3) Nested session protection blocks claude -p when launched from within Claude Code - fix: 'env -u CLAUDECODE'. (4) wt-loop default prompt was tasks.md-centric, ignoring CLAUDE.md workflow - fix: prompt now directs agent to read CLAUDE.md first. (5) Claude Code requires project trust acceptance on first run in new directory - must run claude interactively once before wt-loop can work.

shodh-memory remember() metadata parameter requires Dict[str,str] — all values must be strings. Int/float values cause TypeError. Convert with {str(k):str(v) for k,v in meta.items()}
Memory system quality degraded in v5: 37% noise rate (vs v4 15%), with 16 spurious proactive-context entries. Convention-level knowledge not being captured properly.
Port check in preflight.sh had logic bug: grep -c returns 0 with exit 1 on no match, causing "0\n0" duplication and integer parse failure — fixed with proper conditional
post-session-save.sh successfully extracts both Developer Notes corrections and code conventions from change artifacts. Extraction works for both paths (with/without notes).
37% of memories lack `change:` tags — existing hook doesn't inject them; needs explicit tag parameter in memory save calls
Dual-file architecture: when adding features to OpenSpec skills, always check and edit both SKILL.md and the corresponding command file. Use diff to verify they match.
Use marker files (.memory) for O(1) runtime checks instead of re-parsing SKILL.md on every hook invocation. One-time check at skill start, fast lookup on every Stop event.

All production memory saves must use post-session mechanical extraction (commit contents + change file Developer Notes), not ambient agent volunteering. Hook-based extraction requires dedup to prevent redundant LLM calls.
